articles.headline: Bush Talks Up Dollar as He Heads to Europe
articles.snippet: Amid soaring oil prices and worrisome inflation, the White House is joining with the Federal Reserve in calling for an end to the dollar’s slump.
articles.abstract: Amid soaring oil prices and worrisome inflation, the White House is joining with the Federal Reserve in calling for an end to the dollar’s slump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Bush, departing Monday for a weeklong trip to Europe, promised to stress “our nation’s commitment to a strong dollar”  a signal that, amid soaring oil prices and worrisome inflation, the White House is joining with the Federal Reserve in calling for an end to the dollar’s slump.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Steven R. Weisman

articles.headline: King Coal Country Debates a Sacrilege, Gas Heat
articles.snippet: Officials in the heart of Pennsylvania’s coal mining region are considering using natural gas at county facilities.
articles.abstract: Officials in the heart of Pennsylvania’s coal mining region are considering using natural gas at county facilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: POTTSVILLE, Pa.  Over the last 150 years, Schuylkill County has been famous for a rare hard coal called anthracite that fed the explosive growth of the East Coast during the Industrial Revolution, fostered the rise of the United Mine Workers union and powered many of the factories that supplied troops through both world wars.

articles.headline: Worries Mount as Farmers Push for Big Harvest
articles.snippet: As the world clamors for more corn, wheat, soybeans and rice, farmers are trying to meet the challenge.
articles.abstract: As the world clamors for more corn, wheat, soybeans and rice, farmers are trying to meet the challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRIFFIN, Ind.  In a year when global harvests need to be excellent to ease the threat of pervasive food shortages, evidence is mounting that they will be average at best. Some farmers are starting to fear disaster.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Obama, Adopting Economic Theme, Criticizes McCain
articles.snippet: Barack Obama’s attack on John McCain’s economic policies was a move to define the general election campaign by focusing on the economy as a central theme.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama’s attack on John McCain’s economic policies was a move to define the general election campaign by focusing on the economy as a central theme.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C.  With the Democratic stage to himself for the first time, Senator Barack Obama opened a two-week tour of battleground states on Monday, attacking Senator John McCain’s economic policies and moving to focus on the ailing economy as the central theme of the general election campaign.

articles.headline: CSX Grasping at Straws to End Battle
articles.snippet: CSX, one of largest railroad companies in the nation, has managed to turn a proxy contest with a British hedge fund into a matter of national security.
articles.abstract: CSX, one of largest railroad companies in the nation, has managed to turn a proxy contest with a British hedge fund into a matter of national security.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lou Dobbs, wearing an American flag pin in his left lapel, introduced a segment on his CNN program last week with his trademark outrage. “Tonight, there is a new threat to national sovereignty and security: A foreign hedge fund trying to take control of CSX.”

articles.headline: Lehman Posts Loss and Plans to Raise Capital
articles.snippet: The firm posted a loss of $2.8 billion, far exceeding the most pessimistic forecasts, and said that it will raise up to $6 billion in fresh capital from investors.
articles.abstract: The firm posted a loss of $2.8 billion, far exceeding the most pessimistic forecasts, and said that it will raise up to $6 billion in fresh capital from investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard S. Fuld tried for months to persuade Wall Street that Lehman Brothers, the investment bank he runs, could weather the storm in the financial markets. But by last Wednesday his time had run out: Confidence in Lehman seemed to be slipping away.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Louise Story

articles.headline: At Airports, Lines Made for Speed
articles.snippet: A new system, using a ski slope metaphor, has three “self-select” security lines for travelers with various degrees of familiarity with airline checkpoint procedures.
articles.abstract: A new system, using a ski slope metaphor, has three “self-select” security lines for travelers with various degrees of familiarity with airline checkpoint procedures.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Transportation Security Administration is trying to speed up airport screening by asking passengers to choose a line based on their familiarity with checkpoint procedures. But human nature being what it is, this approach may hit its own snags: people typically opt for the shortest line, and all think they are experts.

articles.headline: Smartphones Now Ringing for Women
articles.snippet: In a shift for the phone industry, women have emerged as eager buyers of so-called smartphones.
articles.abstract: In a shift for the phone industry, women have emerged as eager buyers of so-called smartphones.
articles.lead_paragraph: If recent history is any guide, roughly a third of the people snapping up Apple’s new iPhone are likely to tote it in a purse.

articles.headline: Spain, Like U.S., Grapples With Immigration
articles.snippet: In southern Europe, forgiveness plans for immigrants who arrived illegally have helped power economic growth.
articles.abstract: In southern Europe, forgiveness plans for immigrants who arrived illegally have helped power economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID  With the United States riven by calls to legalize millions of illegal immigrants, Americans might consider the possible effects by looking at southern Europe, where illegal immigration has abounded and so have forgiveness plans.

articles.headline: Derivatives Trading Is Scrutinized
articles.snippet: The regulatory step by the Federal Reserve is intended to assure that the failure of a major financial institution would not create the systemic threat seen in March after the collapse of Bear Stearns.
articles.abstract: The regulatory step by the Federal Reserve is intended to assure that the failure of a major financial institution would not create the systemic threat seen in March after the collapse of Bear Stearns.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve moved Monday to overhaul the financial apparatus behind derivatives trading, a regulatory step intended to assure that the failure of a major bank or investment firm would not create the systemic threat seen in March after the collapse of Bear Stearns.
